Roses 2013 Preview: Fencing

28/04/2013

Fencing has long been a strong suit for the White Rose, and York will be confident of picking up the points in these fixtures

Image by

By undefined undefined

Fixtures

Women's 1sts: 9am Saturday, James Hall Alumni Showcase: 12pm Saturday, James Hall Men's 1sts: 3pm Saturday, James Hall Men's 2nds: 2pm Sunday, James Hall Points on offer: 10

2012 results

 York Men's 1sts 135-108 Lancaster Men's 1sts York Women's 1sts 122-135 Lancaster Women's 1sts York Men's 2nds 134-103 Lancaster Men's 2nds

Fencing Club

How have the club performed so far this season?
"The women have had an incredible season. They were narrowly edged out of winning the BUCS Premier League by Edinburgh, which would have equaled Futsal's historic achievement. After a slow start due to some unavoidable availability issues with key fencers, the men's 1st team rallied to a number of back to back victories keeping them in the 1st Division (at the expense of Lancaster!). The 2nds team have had an improved season with many fencers showing great potential for development next year. "York's fencers compete individually at a national level and in some cases have had international experience; this year saw some excellent performances in BUCS individuals and on the national Open circuit, bringing back several medals."
What are you expecting from your Roses fixtures this year?
"All teams are very confident of success while still keeping highly focused on the remaining few weeks of intense training. The women come off the back of a superb season, with particular strength in foil and epee. Star all-rounder and former captain Louise Highton competes for the last time and will want to deliver a resounding score for York; newcomers captain Sophia Henneberg, Lori Button and Jessie Yeung are all pumped for their first Roses. "The men's 1sts struggled somewhat against Lancaster in BUCS due to the strength of the Red Rose's newly bolstered sabre team, but will be at full strength at Roses so hope to shore up that weakness. The epee team has been a highlight throughout spring term and expect to bring York a key advantage at Roses, while the foil team is seeing strong competition for places and should be another strength. Watch out in particular for this season's outgoing captain Bai Huang's insanely fast sabre footwork and foil anchor Dan Cornwell, known for getting in close to opponents and flicking them on the back. On the Lancaster side, be ready for some loud shouting from a very passionate team. "York has assembled an elite alumni team with some great national-level competitors, particular at epee, while the standard from Lancaster remains an unknown to be discovered. Lancaster's 2nds are also a new entity competing in Roses for the first time, but hopefully won't trouble York's rapidly improving 2nd team captained by the physical Ken Perry."
Why should people come and watch your matches?
"The Fencing Club is pulling out all the stops to ensure its fixtures are of the highest quality and is able to do so thanks to becoming a Focus Sport and designated Fixture to Watch on the Saturday. Fencing will take place on a solid metal piste to prevent hits registering on the floor on a raised stage (14m x 2m), with large scoring lights, time and score displays. A senior referee is being drafted in and both returning alumni and Lancaster fencers are offered a special training session on the Friday night. We're even ordering a load of black and gold socks in to aid spectators. "Located close to the Lancaster accommodation in Physics and proud of being York's biggest contributors to the BUCS tally for several years, fencing hope to attract as many spectators as possible to what are sure to be very tense and dramatic fixtures. If previous Roses are anything to go by we'll need all the home support we can get and spectators won't be disappointed: this is our biggest fixture of the year and that'll be apparent from both sides. The club has been training hard this year, now with four sessions a week and a great increase in funding for elite coaching, strength and conditioning, five international athlete scholarships and an added focus on fitness training; we're determined to lead York to a great Roses victory."

Nouse Verdict

Fencing has long been one of York's strong suits and should provide some of the closest competition of the weekend. It was one win a piece for the two men's firsts squads during the BUCS season, so York will be hoping that home advantage proves to be a deciding factor once again, while the second team should have little trouble against a newly formed Red Rose second string. With that, I'd back York to take all 10 points on offer over the weekend, with the women's firsts coming off the back of an impressive season and perfectly poised to avenge last year's defeat.
